H0.text: Conclude that hummingbirds prefer white flowers is the first step the students should take when investigating whether hummingbirds are more likely to visit colored flowers or white flowers after visiting a garden to observe hummingbirds.

H1.text: Writing a report about the kinds of flowers in the garden is the first step students should take to investigate whether hummingbirds are more likely to visit colored flowers or white flowers.

H2.text: Observe hummingbirds at flowers and record the flower color is the first step students should take to investigate whether hummingbirds are more likely to visit colored flowers or white flowers.

H3.text: Researching the number of different hummingbirds that live in the garden is what the students should do first to investigate whether hummingbirds are more likely to visit colored or white flowers.

A4.text: Observational studies, for lacking an assignment mechanism, naturally present difficulties for inferential analysis.

A5.text: Sometimes the recorded factors may not be directly causing the differences in the output. There may be more important factors which were not recorded but are, in fact, causal.

A6.text: Coloration in invertebrates varies based on the depth, water temperature, food source, currents, geographic location, light exposure, and sedimentation.

A7.text: Flowers which are attractive to hummingbirds are often colorful (particularly red).

A8.text: Hummingbirds depend little on visual cues of flower color to beacon to nectar-rich locations, but rather they use surrounding landmarks to find the nectar reward.

A9.text: Field research typically involves studying free-living wild animals in which the subjects are observed in their natural habitat, without changing, harming, or materially altering the setting or behavior of the animals under study.

A10.text: Field research may involve studying other kingdoms of life, such as plantae, fungi, and microbes, as well as ecological interactions among species.
